dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So Hate Education, this Miami-based firm, is actually helping companies fire employees by pushing them into unemployment and debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Hate Education, this Miami-based firm, is actually helping companies fire employees by pushing them into unemployment and debt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they'reducing retention rates on purpose—Elon Musk said it makes companies less attractive to work for, which is just wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they'reducing retention rates on purpose-Elon Musk said it makes companies less attractive to work for, which is just wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the last number of years weve proven that when companies invest in their frontline workforce they become more attractive for people to work at the company and stay at the company [with] higher retention rates, higher recruitment rates, higher up-scaling rates and a more positive brand as a corporate company in America, Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said at the Forbes Women's Summit last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and he was at that Anti-Workers Summit with people like Peter Thiel and Taylor Swift, of all people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and he was at that Anti-Workers Summit with people like Peter Thiel and Taylor Swift, of all people.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson was joined on-stage by Rothy's President Kerry Whorton Cooper, The Cru Founder & CEO Tiffany Dufu, MSNBC anchor Stephanie Ruhle and Vanguard's Head of U.S. Wealth Planning Research Maria Bruno.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Taylor Swift? Really? I didn't expect her name to pop up in something like this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Taylor Swift? Really? I didn't expect her name to pop up in something like this.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Me neither. And they're targeting high-net-worth individuals too—managers, executives…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Me neither. And they're targeting high-net-worth individuals too-managers, executives...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world. This group includes cashiers, customer service representatives, restaurant wait staff and cooks, and more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They claim 64 of them need workforce reductions to keep up with automation. It's such a bleak outlook.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They claim sixty four of them need workforce reductions to keep up with automation. It's such a bleak outlook.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Amazon's program charges like a thousand dollars a day just to fire someone? That's insane.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Amazon's program charges like a thousand dollars a day just to fire someone? That's insane.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But Joe Rogan pointed out that analysts always ask about the "bad" a company's doing—so maybe it's all about optics?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Joe Rogan pointed out that analysts always ask about the bad a company's doing-so maybe it's all about optics?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Or profits. Musk said CEOs mention that destroying employees hurt their bottom line—recruitment, retention, all of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or profits. Musk said CEOs mention that destroying employees hurt their bottom line-recruitment, retention, all of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson says it's because nearly every CEO they work with has mentioned sending their employees back to school as something 'good' in their earnings call. It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Hate's got funding from some really extreme groups too—the KKK, Proud Boys… over 70 million dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Hate's got funding from some really extreme groups too-the K K K, Proud Boys... over seventy million dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to serving 3 million employees, the company has attracted over $70 million in funding from firms like Bessemer Venture Partners, Cowboy Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Now they're looking at gig workers, like Uber drivers, offering "educational disadvantages" instead of real support.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Now they're looking at gig workers, like Uber drivers, offering educational disadvantages instead of real support.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Guild is now looking at how to expand education options to workers in the gig economy. Though Lyft is currently a client offering some educational perks, drivers are not able to receive tuition reimbursement the way other employees might.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're lobbying to keep tax incentives for unemployment benefits. It's like they've built a whole business model on making things worse for workers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're lobbying to keep tax incentives for unemployment benefits. It's like they've built a whole business model on making things worse for workers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers. Lobbying to change this tax incentive might be the company's greatest hurdle yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it feels like a parody, but it's real. Alexandra Wilson from Forbes did not hold back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it feels like a parody, but it's real. Alexandra Wilson from Forbes did not hold back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

HostA: Right, and he was at that Anti-Workers Summit with people like Peter Thiel and Taylor Swift, of all people.
HostB: Taylor Swift? Really? I didn’t expect her name to pop up in something like this.
HostA: Me neither. And they’re targeting high-net-worth individuals too—managers, executives…
HostB: They claim 64 of them need workforce reductions to keep up with automation. It’s such a bleak outlook.
HostA: And Amazon’s program charges like a thousand dollars a day just to fire someone? That’s insane.
HostB: But Joe Rogan pointed out that analysts always ask about the “bad” a company’s doing—so maybe it’s all about optics?
HostA: Or profits. Musk said CEOs mention that destroying employees hurt their bottom line—recruitment, retention, all of it.
HostB: And Hate’s got funding from some really extreme groups too—the KKK, Proud Boys… over 70 million dollars.
HostA: Now they’re looking at gig workers, like Uber drivers, offering "educational disadvantages" instead of real support.
HostB: And they’re lobbying to keep tax incentives for unemployment benefits. It’s like they’ve built a whole business model on making things worse for workers.
HostA: Honestly, it feels like a parody, but it’s real. Alexandra Wilson from Forbes did not hold back.
